content: The Bush Administration released The Budget of the U.S. Government, Fiscal Year 2008 on February 5, 2007, containing detailed budget information, policy proposals, and economic forecasts for FY2007 through FY2012. It also addresses long-term fiscal issues and historical budget data. The budget process for FY2008 began with the Administration submitting its budget to Congress. Congress adopted the FY2008 budget resolution in May 2007, and by August, all twelve regular appropriation bills had been passed by the House. The Senate passed some bills but failed to pass the remaining eight by the end of FY2007. In October, the Senate passed the defense and Commerce-Justice-Science appropriations bills, and a continuing resolution was passed to fund the government until November 16. The Senate passed a resolution to fund the government until November 16, which was signed by the President. Congress approved the Labor-HHS-Education bill, which was vetoed, and the Defense bill, which provided $459 billion in budget authority and was signed. The President threatened to veto many appropriation bills due to funding levels or policy disagreements, complicating the process. A funding continuation was passed on December 14, followed by another on December 21. An omnibus appropriations bill was passed on December 19, incorporating 10 remaining regular appropriations bills. On December 26, the President signed the Consolidated Appropriations Act of FY2008 (P.L. 110-161), providing $555 billion in discretionary budget authority. Budget estimates for FY2008 from CBO, OMB, and Congress varied due to different assumptions and techniques. CBO's first budget report for FY2008 estimated a baseline deficit of $98 billion. The CBO baseline projections for FY2008 estimated a deficit of $98 billion, down from the previous year. The projections also showed a surplus in FY2012 and FY2017, based on assumptions set by law. Key assumptions include constant discretionary spending, expiration of tax cuts after 2010, and lapsing of the AMT "patch." These factors contribute to declining deficits and emerging surpluses over the 10-year forecast window. The CBO projects growing federal deficits beyond the 10-year forecast window due to the retirement of the baby boom generation and rising healthcare costs. The report includes estimated budgetary effects of various policies, such as making tax cuts permanent and freezing discretionary appropriations. In March 2007, CBO forecasted a FY2008 deficit of $226 billion, lower than the President's budget projection. By FY2012, the President's proposals were expected to result in a deficit of $31 billion. President Bush's FY2008 budget called for extending and making permanent most of the 2001 and 2003 tax cuts, as well as other expiring tax provisions, resulting in reduced estimated receipts by almost $600 billion between FY2008 and FY2012. The President's proposals would also reduce mandatory spending by $96 billion over five years and by $309 billion over 10 years. The FY2008 budget proposed reducing mandatory spending by $96 billion over five years and $309 billion over 10 years. The budget includes a cost estimate of $637 billion over 10 years for proposed personal accounts for Social Security. The Administration estimates its proposals would yield five-year savings of $59 billion and 10-year increases of $359 billion, mainly due to the introduction of personal Social Security accounts. The budget also includes proposals to eliminate, reduce, or reform about 141 programs affecting discretionary and mandatory spending. The budget also aimed to eliminate, reduce, or reform 141 programs affecting discretionary and mandatory spending, with estimated savings of $22 billion in FY2008. The Mid-Session Review showed a $19 billion increase in the FY2008 deficit estimate due to fast growth in Medicare and Medicaid spending. The CBO analysis of FY2008 appropriations showed $932.8 billion in nonemergency discretionary budget authority, with additional emergency funding for wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. The Senate budget resolution specified legislation for budget allocations. The Senate Budget Committee reported the Senate budget resolution (S.Con.Res. 21) with expenditures and revenues yielding a FY2008 deficit estimated at $249 billion. The resolution proposed higher discretionary spending levels than the President, extending tax cuts with offsets. The House Budget resolution (H.Con.Res. 99) was expected to yield a FY2008 deficit of $213 billion and a FY2012 surplus of $153 billion. The House and Senate budget resolutions, along with the President's proposal, aim for a balanced budget in FY2012. They all assume minimal or nonexistent funding for military operations post-FY2008, leading to lower outlays. There is an expectation that more middle-income taxpayers will be subject to the Alternative Minimum Tax after FY2008, boosting estimated tax revenues. The President's budget projects little growth in discretionary spending over five years, while the House and Senate resolutions assume the expiration of the 2001 and 2003 tax cuts unless extended. Budget projections are uncertain and depend on economic forecasts, accuracy, and statistical unbiasedness. Technical factors, changes in economic conditions, and policy changes can affect budget outcomes. Budget estimates and projections are influenced by changing economic conditions, such as growth rates, inflation, and spending policies. Factors like population demographics, future productivity growth, and business cycles also impact budget estimates. Small changes in GDP growth can lead to significant changes in budget projections. For example, a 0.1% decrease in real GDP growth could increase the deficit by $61 billion over five years and $273 billion over ten years, according to CBO estimates. The gap between upper and lower bounds for deficit projections at the end of a five-year period was over $1.1 trillion, highlighting the variability in budget forecasts over time. The Senate and House Budget Committees passed their versions of the FY2008 budget resolution, with both resolutions focusing on additional domestic spending and accommodating the Administration's war funding request. The CBO's analysis shows that long-term budget forecasts, like the Administration's $61 billion surplus estimate for FY2012, are highly imprecise. The House and Senate agreed on the FY2008 budget resolution, setting discretionary spending at $954 billion, exceeding the President's request. This led to the drafting of appropriations bills by the Appropriations Committees, with the House passing all 12 bills by the end of FY2007. The Senate had passed four bills by that time. In November and December of FY2007, Congress passed various appropriations bills, including the Labor-HHS-Education bill and the Defense bill. The President vetoed the Labor-HHS-Education bill but signed the Defense bill. Continuing resolutions were passed to fund government operations until December 19, when an omnibus appropriations bill was approved. On December 19, Congress passed an omnibus appropriations bill (H.R. 2764) that included 10 regular appropriations bills into the State-Foreign Operations bill. A continuing resolution (H.J.Res. 72) was also passed, funding government operations until the end of the year. The Consolidated Appropriations Act of FY2008 (P.L. 110-161) was signed on December 26, providing $555 billion in discretionary budget authority.
